awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Scalable CO2 electrolyzers for the production of ethylene glycol and chlorine
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this STTR project is the technical and economic demonstration of a device for the the polymer chemical industry. Ethylene glycol is primarily used in the production of plastics for textiles and food packaging. Chlorine is a major industrial chemical used in water purification and fabrication of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) fabrication. This proposed electrochemical process utilizes waste carbon dioxide and renewable electricity, resulting in net carbon-negative emissions, unlike petrochemical sourcing. Combining ethylene glycol and the co-production of chlorine will make the overall process cost-competitive with production from fossil feedstocks, while supporting environmental sustainability. This platform technology holds promise for an extension to other parts of the chemical industry. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to address the sustainable co-production of three major chemicals by one unitized device: Chlorine (Cl2), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), and ethylene glycol from renewable electricity, brine, and carbon dioxide. Current carbon dioxide reduction (CO2RR) suffers from three major constraints: 1) high electricity costs, 2) low relative price of bulk chemicals, and 3) low energy efficiency of CO2 reduction. This project will address these constraints by using recently developed energy efficient CO2RR to ethylene glycol catalysts and co-producing Cl2 and NaOH to offset the electricity cost and low ethylene glycol price. Three technical barriers that result from combing Cl2, NaOH, and CO2RR will be addressed: A) Producing Cl2 and NaOH, which requires strict product separation (leading to less valuable hypochlorite and impure NaOH); B) Maintaining three different pH conditions in the cell (acidic for chlorine, basic for alkali, and neutral for CO2RR); and C) Providing fundamental insights into the membrane, electrode, and electrolyzer designs for complex multiproduct processes. These will be addressed by combined experiments and modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: Scalable CO2 electrolyzers for the production of ethylene glycol and chlorine

Project Outcomes Report

The broader impact/commercial potential of this STTR project was the technical and economic demonstration of the unitized co-production of ethylene glycol and chlorine using renewable electricity, salt-water/brine, and carbon dioxide (CO2). The final products have a net negative carbon footprint, consuming carbon dioxide emissions. Both products are used by the plastics industry: ethylene glycol in the production of PET (polyethylene terephthalate) for textiles and food packaging, and chlorine (Cl2) in PVC (polyvinyl chloride) fabrication. Co-production of ethylene glycol and Cl2 would be a disruptive technology serving environmentally sustainable markets that is cost-advantaged in comparison with the incumbent processes. This platform technology holds promise for an extension to other parts of the chemical industry, fundamentally changing how we view carbon dioxide, from a waste product to a feedstock.

Current carbon dioxide reduction (CO2RR) suffers from three major constraints: 1) high electricity costs, 2) low relative price of bulk chemicals, and 3) low energy efficiency of CO2 reduction. This project addresses these constraints by: 1) use the recently developed energy efficient CO2RR to ethylene glycol catalysts, 2) co-producing Cl2 and NaOH to offset the electricity cost; and 3) technical integration barriers that result from combing the production of Cl2, NaOH, with CO2 reduction.

The technical challenges addressed during this project were two-fold:

  • The electrosynthesis of Cl2 and NaOH requires strict product separation, at the risk of having less valuable hypochlorite and impure NaOH.
  • Three different pH conditions need to be maintained in the cell (acidic for chlorine, basic for alkali, and neutral for CO2RR).

Fundamental insights into the membrane, electrode, and electrolyzer designs for complex multiproduct processes to overcome these challenges were evaluated by combining experiments and techno-economic modeling.

In this NSF-STTR, RenewCO2 and Rutgers have successfully demonstrated the operation of a unitized device able to perform CO2 reduction to multi-carbon products at the cathode and chlorine at the anode. Faradaic efficiency was shown to be 100% for the CO2RR and 80% for CER at current densities of 1 mA/cm2. The catalyst stability was evaluated under these conditions, showing no difference in performance in comparison with the CO2 + OER case. The CO2 reduction process was translated from a batch system to a continuous process, where critical dependence of performance on loading was observed. Temperature and pressure dependance were also evaluated, with increasing temperature favoring the competing HER and pressure showing an optimum at moderate pressures. Techno-economic analysis of the combined process showed that the levelized product costs would be competitive in the current market, including with current industrial costs of electricity, current cost of carbon dioxide capture, and current cost of plastics. The combined process would, therefore, enable the production of well-known plastics used in everyday applications but with a net positive impact on the environment.

This project also trained a graduate student as well as disseminated the knowledge to several aspiring undergraduate students and more broadly the scientific community through submitted peer-reviewed publications.

Market analysis showed that there are only four polymer producers that produces both mono-ethylene glycol and chlorine for PVC. Furthermore, these facilities are seldom co-located due to the different requirements feedstock. This split in the market offers a barrier for the market penetration of the combined process investigated. The lack of pressure (legislative or consumer) to introduce green processes that reaches this segment of the supply chain impedes the current economic appetite for this co-production process. The changing attitude in the chemical industry towards green projects could overcome the above issues in the longer to medium term. The production of only one of the chemicals from CO2 would overcome the market co-location issues as long as the process economics are brought to a point of being competitive on cost with conventional petrochemical derived products. Examples of CO2 reduction products that are projected to be cost-competitive at electricity costs below $40/MWh include formic acid for agriculture feed preservation, potassium formate for green de-icers, mono-ethylene glycol for green polyester, and ethanol amongst others.


Last Modified: 05/30/2022
Modified by: Anders B Laursen
